results.title: One more river
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Douglas Leiterman and Beryl Fox
results.brief_description: A report on the mood of the ‘deep south’ states of the United States, where racial segregation has been an accepted way of life for hundreds of years and where integration is now making slow progress. Includes interviews with Blacks and Whites in different parts of the southern United States - South Carolina, Alabama, Mississippi - and also features some actuality films of some of the situations that are encountered every day in the south, such as a Black couple being refused admission to a movie theatre.

results.title: One Monday morning
results.brief_description: Every day a King, a Queen, a little Prince and one or two or three or more extra people come to visit a little boy…but he is never home until Sunday when the people and a little dog call on him. Based on the words and pictures by Uri Shulevitz.

results.title: One man's war
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, Jack S. Allan and Tom Gurr
results.brief_description: Made to encourage a better understanding of the meaning of the war in Korea. The film conveys impressions of the war as experienced by an Australian infantryman. Photographed on the Australian troopship, in Japan and on the South Korean battlefields.

results.title: One Man's Walk
results.creator_credit: First Light, Interplay Theatre and Kenneth Mitchell
results.brief_description: A boy walks down a street. We do not see his face. He is the event but we don’t know why. He tells us his likes and dislikes as he passes through the streets of his town. Finally we see his face and understand.

results.title: One man's view
results.brief_description: “Summary: paul ehrlich is professor of biology and director of graduate studies at stanford university. he is known for the urgency that he attributes to the interacting problems of pollution, population growth and resource

results.title: One man's road
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, John Martin-Jones and Robert Kingsbury
results.brief_description: The life of an Aborigine and his family in reserves, country situations and Sydney. Clive and Ida Williams recall the disadvantages typical of most Aborigines’ lives in New South Wales which prevent full participation in society, and their successful assimilation in the city.

results.title: One man's opinion
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “What Do You Think”.
First in a series of discussion-provoking subjects, this film shows how one person’s judgment might reasonably run counter to the majority opinion. This is illustrated in a high-school classroom where a campaign is under way to raise funds for a school project. One student, although he believes in the cause, withholds his support because he disapproves of the high-pressure methods which put individuals on the spot if they are unable to or do not wish to contribute. The audience is asked for their appraisal.
